Row.Text: A Triumphal Arch is a large Arch with one or more arched passageways.It is often found spanning roads and in it's simplest form consists of two piers connectect by an arch with a flat entablature on which a statue might be mounted or which bears commemrative inscriptions. It is often associated with ancient rome but examples can be found all across the world including the Wellingtion Arch (Marble Arch) in London and the Arch de Triomphe in Paris.
Floodplains do not block placement of commercial hubs, which are provided with an adjacency bonus from all floodplain and oasis tiles. +1 [ICON_Gold] gold for each city following Punt's religion.
The Triumphal Arch replaces the monument and grants double the [ICON_Culture] culture output of one
The worker has an extra charge than the builder it replaces

To survive, a civilization needs skilled workers. They may be highly trained engineers, or civilians conscripted into labour - or, indeed, slaves - but someone has to dig the mines, plant the fields and pave the roads. Without these men and women, a civilization will stagnate and eventually fall prey to a more vigorous neighbour.
Gains an additional economic government slot. Incoming trade routes from other civilizations provide +2 [ICON_Gold] gold for the Punt.

Greetings oh mighty Albion. You have led the Lombards to found what will become modern Italy. Can you now expand your borders to form a civilzation to compare to the Roman Empire before you? Can you hold together your coalition of forces and conquer other lands? Or will you seek to form a society based upon culture rather than the sword?

Albion was king of the Lombards. During his reign the Lombards ended their migrations by settling in Italy, the northern part of which Alboin conquered. Albion was later assasinated by the Byzantines in a coup d'etat organised by Helmichis, his foster brother who was supported by Albion's wife Rosamund. Most of the Lombards opposed this and it failed.

In 568 AD Albion, a young leader of the Lombards, led the Lombard migration into Italy. At least 20,000 Saxon warriors joined them with their families. The first city to fall was Forum Iulii in 569 AD. Verona, Vicenza and Bresica soon followed. Milan fell to the Lombards in the summer of 569 AD as the small Byzantine army guarding it could do nothing to prevent it. They continued to conquer further south. At it's height the Lombard territory was divided into 36 duchies, whose leaders settled in the major cities of each duchy. However this subdivision led to weakness. After the assaination of Albion and his successor Celph there was a period known as the Rule of Dukes when no King was elected until 584 AD.
